manifests/phases/executors.yaml.message: Why do we need this executor? Let's include a comment explaining the use case.

I have added the reason for no-wait support in commit message, but now updated as comment in manifest also.
=> if there is a wait, then it does status check and pass/fails based on the status condition. However if the resource did not implement status field properly, the status check will always fail looking for a undefined status as part of conditions. One of the CR (installation) of Tigera operator did not have condition within status field implemented. So wait always fails to check the status of that resources though it is in Running state.

manifests/phases/phases.yaml.message: Is it necessary to add another phase just for the operator?

It is added to address an issue (status condition not implemented properly) with one of the resources (installation CR) of Operator. We could not apply this operator as part of the existing phase with timeout. When there is a timeout for a phase, then it checks for status of all resources applied and pass/fail based on the result.
So introduced new executor `kubernetes-apply-nowait` to run phase with nowait.

is_server_error(0) returns... false?  maybe "0" isn't a great answer to cache for "not is_success"

OK, got more context loaded up in my head around this: the container info really *was* coming out 404, so this isn't going to help the way I thought it would 😞

The trouble was an internal-client running on a node with very stale ring files (it had been disabled and wasn't supposed to be participating in the cluster). I don't think there's a good way for us to defend against that short of:

* getting rings loaded up in the backend servers' heads,
* sending back headers like "yeah, I think I'm supposed to be responsible for this partition" or "you were expecting me to be a hand-off, right?", and then
* having the proxy ignore 404s from backends that say they're handoffs.

Then the client with the stale rings would've gotten nothing but 503s, but at least it wouldn't go poisoning the cache. The downside, of course, would be needing to load up rings for every worker of every service...

Maybe I should revisit https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670674/.

I don't think we *do* cache the zero, though -- we just might return it to callers :-/

This is the part of the change I care about, btw -- I got reports of proxies querying the wrong policy when there was a container-layer failure. Only container HEADs that came back were 404s (don't remember for sure if they were from handoffs or primaries-during-a-rebalance), but I think the container controller must've arrived at a 503 response.

The thing is, going to disk is *sometimes a reasonable thing to do*, even with a 503 from the container layer. If we always did the 503, it could cause availability issues for clusters with large container DBs but only one policy.

As it is, this patch *does* cause availability issues for clusters with more than one policy and most of the large containers were in policy zero, but I'm not sure that's a compelling reason to erroneously respond with 404 for containers with data *not* in policy zero.

As this is a kind of neutron problem on high concurrency, how are we planning to address it and still reduce or keep the same deployment time at scale?

I actually think the node + ports provisioning as implemented in the WiP patches would be able to deploy 1000 nodes and it's ports in one go. With the concurrency setting in the ansible modules we control how many nodes and ports we try to provision in parallel so it would just churn trough. (I did try 1000 nodes = 3000 ports with my ansible module to create ports, and it ran trough. A VM, on my laptop with 8 vCPU's the create took: real 17m35.103s to create the 3000 ports.

The node provisioning and port provisioning could be "paralellized" simply by running them as async tasks in ansible. That means we'll be finished creating ports way before baremetal provisioning is done in any case.

The question is will we still have to update the heat stack in incremements, or will the pre-provisioned nodes and ports allow Heat to churn trough 1000 nodes. Was'nt the problem with heat that the stack create/update operation has a timeout that we would always hit when waiting for so many baremetal's to be provisioned?

> The question is will we still have to update the heat stack in incremements, or will the pre-provisioned nodes and ports allow Heat to churn trough 1000 nodes.

Heat can use high concurrency since OSP13 with increased number of workers. The issue has been throttling it for specific resources as heat treats every resource as equal.

> Was'nt the problem with heat that the stack create/update operation has a timeout that we would always hit when waiting for so many baremetal's to be provisioned?

Heat stack create/update timeout is configurable from the beginning and I've never seen it timing out for provisioning large number baremetal of nodes unless nova does not report back an error. The only issue I know was with neutron with higher concurrency (as mentioned earlier) since OSP13. If that can throttled with configurable concurrency in the ansible module with proper error handling, then it should be fine I guess.

> Scaling in increments when deploying large clouds.

IMO, a single baremetal yaml provided (with all node details), but then be able to provision both nodes/network ports in batches would be required and the whole operation has to be idempotent as it is now for nodes.

I did a tiny bit of performance testing using the ansible module that will create ports:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/761908

It's using threads for concurrency, and many CPU cores and higher CPU clock seem to make a difference. And also tuning the number of threads.

Both tests ran on libvirt/openstack virtual machine.

Create 300 ports in ~2 minutes, and updating them in just ~5-10 seconds. I think we recoment scaling in increments when deploying large clouds, so deploy in increments of 100 computes with default network isolation will spend ~2 minutes on port creation. Hopefully this is better than what we got with Heat.

It would also be good to try such a test run on some real server hardware that is similar to what we expect large scale operators would use for their Undercloud.


Performance stats: 100 nodes x 3 networks = 300 ports

        4xCPU 1.8 GHz (8GB)             8x CPU 2.6 GHz (12GB)
        -------------------  --------------------------------
Concurr:                 10          20         10          4
........     ..............   .........  .........  .........
Create       real 5m58.006s   1m48.518s  1m51.998s  1m25.022s
Delete:      real 4m12.812s   0m47.475s  0m48.956s  1m19.543s
Re-run:      real 0m19.386s    0m4.389s   0m4.453s   0m4.977s

NOTE: On slow system concurrency ~15 resulted in 504 Gateway
      timeout. On the faster ~30 caused 504 GW timeout.
      It's also not neccecarily better to use a high number,
      but using concurrency = 1 is way slower.

How tight?

Ideally we need to move towards being more loosely coupled so that we're able to test things more independently.

If this enables an easy integration point with a well known set of interfaces, then that's great. If this adds another tightly coupled component into the architecture, then I don't think that's good at all.

In my view, this should be optional. Operators will make use of it if they can afford to implement and maintain another system - but that system should not be integrated into our installer and our installer should not rely on it.

To be clear, using AWX is 100% optional from an operator's perspective. The main goals boil down to these two points: (1) allow our Ansible content to be more modular and (2) allow the TripleO client to interact with the AWX API for running playbooks. I will work on updating this spec with more emphasis on those points.

test/unit/__init__.py.message:
I feel like this always trips me up: the difference between calling

 x.close()

and

 y = iter(x)
 ...
 y.close()

is subtle so I almost always end up doing exactly this with my iterables/iterators so I can do either to achieve the same thing.

I wonder if it would be worth having some helpers where the distinction is easier to write assertions against...

agree, the subtlety creates a pitfall. I considered (briefly) having the CloseableChain take not only the iters to be chained, but also 'other objects that might have a close() method' so that it could be passed both x and y and just try to close *everything*.

test/unit/common/test_utils.py.message:
I wonder if it'd be worth throwing in some assertions with generators, too, like

diff --git a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
index c59172098..d7a704ff7 100644
--- a/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
+++ b/test/unit/common/test_utils.py
@@ -8836,3 +8836,29 @@ class TestCloseableChain(unittest.TestCase):
         chain = utils.CloseableChain([1, 2], [3])
         chain.close()
         self.assertEqual([1, 2, 3], [x for x in chain])
+
+        generator_closed = [False]
+        def gen():
+            try:
+                yield 2
+                yield 3
+            except GeneratorExit:
+                generator_closed[0] = True
+                raise
+        test_iter1 = FakeIterable([1])
+        chain = utils.CloseableChain(test_iter1, gen())
+        self.assertEqual(0, test_iter1.close_call_count)
+        self.assertFalse(generator_closed[0])
+        chain.close()
+        self.assertEqual(1, test_iter1.close_call_count)
+        # Generator never kicked off, so there's no GeneratorExit
+        self.assertFalse(generator_closed[0])
+
+        test_iter1 = FakeIterable([1])
+        chain = utils.CloseableChain(gen(), test_iter1)
+        self.assertEqual(2, next(chain))  # Kick off the generator
+        self.assertEqual(0, test_iter1.close_call_count)
+        self.assertFalse(generator_closed[0])
+        chain.close()
+        self.assertEqual(1, test_iter1.close_call_count)
+        self.assertTrue(generator_closed[0])

tempest/lib/api_schema/response/compute/.message: what is the reason for redefining this? why not to deepcopy one from 2.1? see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/338201/ for example

Yea that's what we do not want to do for readability reason.

We have those deepcopy used everywhere which going to be disappear soon. Each schema will be well defined itself so that we do not need to iterate to files/other schema to understand complete response.

Yea i agree that this is little bit hard to review. For changes in schema i added comment in schema(# NOTE(gmann): new attributes in version 2.3).

There are two thing which we need to trade off
- hard to review when adding new schema which extend the old one - This one is one time effort.

- Easy to read. Later anyone want to see complete schema for debugging or quick glance, it will be present in single place. 

If we use deepcopy, I agree it will be easy to review and see detla but it makes very complicated to understand the complete schema.
For example - you cannot understand schema of keypair v2.2 without iterating many schema and files. - https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/lib/api_schema/response/compute/v2_2/keypairs.py

For old schema also i would like to do the same, please check this - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/306245/

I think the current approach with deep copy has the advantage that it highlights what changed - it's hard to see it with the full schema, and certainly harder to review.

It should be easy enough to print out the whole schema if needed.

IMO, we should go for better readability here than optimization of schema code. Schema servers the goal of finding the complete response of any API quickly along with finding the difference between versions. and difference can be taken always by comparing the file.
That was my point. I'd like to see a delta between the previous version and the current one. And here it's hard to find out what exactly was changed

README.md.message: kind will have severe limitations for vino development - eg only being able to run a single libvirt per Linux kernel, but more importantly oddities when breaking out of container cgroups. I would recommend kubeadm or minikube with the none provider for now.

Thanks for the feedback Pete! These are great points, I think I've captured them in the latest revision. I chose to leave the KIND instructions in place for users not needing the libvirt/cgroup features and desiring a simple deployment but added a note on the limitations and recommended setup via kubeadm. I've also added a quick start guide on setting up a developer environment via a single node kubeadm setup. Please let me know if you have any additional feedback.
sure why we would want to encourage the use of kind when it wont work for the most basic of vino functionality? Vino exists to support the LCM of Libvirt domains.
Removed KIND make targets and examples in the README. What's left is a sample kubeadm single node setup with an example configuration that can be tailored to the users' needs.

this is not a limitation of kind, but one of libvirt as orchestrated by vino - its why i would not recommend the use of things like kind (which will attempt to create several kubernetes nodes on a single host) for VINO development.
Removed as mentioned in other comment.

rather than a verbose set of commands without ci, perhaps it would be better to link to one of the scripts that is used by airship to do this, eg: https://opendev.org/airship/charts/src/branch/master/tools/gate/deploy-k8s.sh for example, which is validated, and updated regularly. Additionally as network policy should be supported, a CNI that supports that (eg Calico) would be a better fit and fannel.
another advantage of using the above is that it already supports things like running behind corporate proxies, and has accompanying documentation.

Thanks Pete! The latest revision leverages the script mentioned above and includes the pre-requisites of Golang and Kustomize installations and a snippet on proxy configuration. to the swift egg. We use the PBR package that converts
it into the actual egg during "python setup.py build".

Isn't this backwards? If we do "disregard", then no need to even do get_info, right? In all other cases, get_info and all the other machinery.

tacker/conductor/conductor_server.py.message: Why don't you make it one line, length is <80?
Thank you for detail explanation, Yoshito. I totally agree with you.

It has been agreed that this variable should be an uuid by previous spec.
At least it works correctly as a VNF, so it is no problem.
If there is an impact on DB by CNF implementation, it should be discussed with creating a new spec, I think.

cf. https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tacker-specs/specs/ussuri/etsi-nfv-sol-rest-api-for-VNF-deployment.html

I believe we have no choice other than accepting this change.

But it's wrong to say this change is accepted in the spec because this part tries to store "instance_id" in "vnf" table, which is for Legacy implementation, and it's not described in the spec. The spec only describes for "vnf_instantiated_info" table. On the other hand, the existing implementation is already highly depending on "vnf" table. It's not easy to solve this dependency so we have to accept this logic to quickly fix the Scale operation now.

Also, let me say that "instance_id" in "vnf_instantiated_info" is already accepted to be changed to TEXT in the following spec in Victoria release.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tacker-specs/specs/victoria/container-network-function.html#data-model-impact

tacker/db/migration/alembic_migrations/v.message: Could you tell me why you use raw sql although we use sqlalchemy?

In this issue, "GENERATED ALWAYS AS" is used as the definition of the column. To avoid the issue, I tried changing code with using op.alter_column, but it didn't work correctly. Since an addition was supported in alembic 1.3.3, the change has not been supported. Due to this reason, I use raw SQL with op.exec.
Should it be removed? If so, you have made same mistake in `d25c7c86..._mod_vnflcm_subscription.py:85`
It is removed. As for d25c7c86..._mod_vnflcm_subscription.py, also fixed in this patch since the change is so small.

specs/wallaby/share-size-limited-by-shar.message:
Should these two extra specifications be user visible?

Also, 

These aren't scoped in any way, so you'll have to take extra-care to discard them in the capabilities filtering. In contrast, in cinder, they're scoping extra-specs like this with a "provisioning:" [1]
Should we do the same, so the scheduler filters automatically discard these keys?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/713710

1:i think it can be user visible, even in the name of share type, can indicate its restriction rule, such as backend1_max_10_min_2.
2:yes, we'd better scoping extra-specs with a "provisioning:", scheduler will automatically ignore them.i will add it.

Great, thanks. 

If you make another patchset, please clarify that:

these two extra specifications will be visible to end users. If they're not set, it is assumed that there are no share size limits enforced by the share type; but limits may be enforced by the service and the user's quotas.
yes, it is necessary to clarify it here.
